description: Borrowed into Middle English from Anglo-Norman vultur, from Old French voutoir, voutre, from Latin vultur, voltur.

entries.meaning: Any of several carrion-eating birds of the families Accipitridae and Cathartidae.
(figurative, colloquial) A person who profits from the suffering of others.
examples: Within ten minutes of the accident, the vultures appeared and were organizing lawsuits.

verbs.description: vulture (third-person singular simple present vultures, present participle vulturing, simple past and past participle vultured)

entries.meaning: (figurative, colloquial) To circle around one's target as if one were a vulture.
examples: Rudy vultured when asking the girl out.
